В полку качественных головоломок пополнение. Знакомьтесь - Archaica: The Path of Light. 

Весь так называемый сюжет рассказывается в коротеньком предложении в подобии катсцены при каждом запуске игры. Есть умирающий мирок, есть спасительный свет, есть несущий этот спасительный свет - вы. Кратко, лаконично, без лишних вопросов.

В дальнейшем о том, что в игре есть какая-то суть, нам будут напоминать всякие философские фразы, которые пытаются пролить свет на историю местного мира, но выглядят как высосанные из пальца и привязанные белыми нитками мифы. К сожалению, благодаря им не возникает ощущение целостного повествования.

Но к счастью, геймплей вышел гораздо более проработанным. Суть проста: есть луч, который нужно направить в конкретную точку. Разумеется, через ряд препятствий. Сначала в наше распоряжение выдают только один луч с одной конечной точкой и зеркала, которые могут отражать его в разных направлениях. Поначалу игра кажется очень, даже слишком простой и казуальной, но...

Стоит пройти первую локацию, как количество элементов на уровнях резко увеличивается. Появляются зеркала нескольких видов, которые различаются тем, под каким углом отражают луч. Появляются агрегаты, разделяющие лучи на несколько частей. Да и самих лучей становится зачастую несколько, как и целей. Помимо этого присутствуют дополнительные механизмы - активировать их не обязательно, но они разблокируют доступ к секретным уровням.

Большое количество элементов в головоломках значительно увеличивают сложность игры. При переходе на новый уровень сразу понимаешь, чего игра от тебя хочет, но иногда требуется немало времени и терпения, чтобы разобраться во всех деталях и правильно расставить их по полю. Помощь от подсказок - минимальная. Конечно, до сложности какой-нибудь The Witness ей далеко, и яростных воплей «Чего вы от меня хотите!?» Archaica не провоцирует. Но по той же причине она совсем не запоминается и вылетает из головы сразу же после прохождения.

Присутствует в игре и некое подобие «казуалки» про поиск предметов. Вращая камеру, на каждой локации можно найти несколько дополнительных объектов. Первый тип - это развалины с иероглифами, которые расскажут немного об истории мира. Второй тип - подсказки в виде кристаллов, которые подсвечивают все клетки, на которые можно поставить выбранный элемент. Всё это не сказать, что очень уж нужно игре, но заядлым перфекционистам может понравиться.

Неплохой тренажёр для мозга, который вы, скорее всего, забудете сразу после прохождения.

36321197.review:
[h1]Archaica – The Path of Light[/h1]
[b]Vydejte se na cestu nosiče světla a zachraňte umírající svět.[/b]
Marcin a Piotr jsou dva polští bratři z Krakova, kteří odmala rádi hráli hry. Po studiích oba nějakou dobu pracovali, než se dali dohromady, a z jejich koníčku se stala profese. Společně založili vývojářské studio TwoMammoths, které před nedávnem poslalo do světa svou první logickou hru – Archaica – The Path of Light. Dokáže tato prvotina založená na známém herním principu zaujmout?

[h1]Na cestě za světlem[/h1] 
Jako vyvolený neznámého národa – nositel světla – se vydáváte na cestu světla, jež má zachránit váš svět. Na této pouti se postupně dozvídáme informace o světě, o světle a všem, s čím se během řešení úkolů setkáte. 
Po cestě různými světy se ocitnete na poušti, v chrámech, dolech na krystaly, džungli či vodním světě. Každý svět má svůj specifický design, místy je světlejší a místy temnější, herní mechaniky jsou ale všude stejné, i když je samozřejmé, že čím dále se propracujete, o to komplikovanější bude řešení úkolů. 
Kromě absolvování jednotlivých levelů, jež vás vedou dál a dál hrou, se vám čas od času podaří splnit úkoly, jež aktivují části totemu. Slouží také jako achievementy, ale pozor, pokud chcete hru kompletně dokončit, totem musí být plně aktivován! 
Po krátkém úvodu, jenž vás seznámí s vaší situací, máte možnost absolvovat tutoriál. Ten vám ukáže, jak se hra ovládá (pouze myší) a jak fungují základní přístroje ve hře, tedy jednotlivá zrcadla, pohyb po ploše a na co si musíte dávat pozor. 

[h1]Zrcadla, paprsky, krystaly[/h1]
Základní premisa je celkem jednoduchá. Máme zdroj světla, paprsek či laser a krystal. Krystaly mají různé barvy a vaším úkolem je propojit zdroje a krystaly stejné barvy. Co se konceptu týče, není to nic závratného. Oproti jiným hrám tohoto žánru však Archaica zaujme především svou vizuální stránkou, jež každou herní plochu obohacuje o rostliny, kameny a útesy a polorozpadlými budovami. A samozřejmě se to celé jaksi vznáší ve vzduchu. 
Návrh jednotlivých úrovní má jistá pravidla. Kromě již zmíněných krystalů a zdrojů světla se ve skoro každém levelu nachází tři baterie, které umožňují využití nápovědy a 2-4 desky s hieroglyfy, které odhalují buď funkčnost jednotlivých zařízení, s nimiž pracujete, nebo části z historie tohoto světa. 
Nápověda v této hře funguje velmi zajímavým způsobem. Na herním poli kliknete na část dlaždic (až 5), a nápověda vám prozradí, zda na některé z nich má být umístěn nějaký přístroj. Zpočátku máte 3-4 nápovědy, pokud s nimi však nevyčistíte celou herní plochu a nevíte, jak dál, nemusíte se bát. Nápověda se postupně dobíjí a pak máte další pokusy. Tento typ nápovědy je velmi sympatický, protože vám sice pomůže, ale nevede vás za ručičku. To, jaký předmět a v jakém úhlu máte na dlaždici umístit, musíte vymyslet sami. 
Součástí některých levelů jsou také „klíče“, speciální místa, na něž musíte paprsek namířit, aby se vám postupně otevřel tajný level. To je sice zajímavé obohacení, škoda pouze je, že pro tuto „nadstavbu“ některých levelů nápovědu využít nemůžete. 

[h1]Záseky[/h1]
Jelikož jde o logickou hru, budete muset občas trochu déle přemýšlet. Úroveň obtížnosti se zvedá postupně, a s postupným přibýváním nejrůznějších přístrojů (od zrcadel, agregátů až po zesilovače paprsků) a do jisté míry rozšiřováním herní plochy, se trošku zapotíte. Pokud se ovšem trápit nechcete, ve většině případů vám pomohou nápovědy. 
„Návrh jednotlivých úrovní má jistá pravidla. Kromě již zmíněných krystalů a zdrojů světla se v každém levelu nachází tři baterie, které umožňují využití nápovědy a 2-4 desky s hieroglyfy, které odhalují buď funkčnost jednotlivých zařízení, s nimiž pracujete, nebo části z historie tohoto světa.“ 

Problém je především v barvách krystalů a síle paprsků. Občas totiž není úplně jasné, jakou barvu paprsek musí mít, respektive kdy přesně musíte pomocí barvených krystalů jeho barvu změnit (před zrcadlem nebo za zrcadlem). Také práce se sílou paprsků je zcela náhodná, vývojáři za tímto jevem nedokazují žádnou logiku, krátké paprsky jsou pouze důsledkem toho, že vývojáři chtěli level komplikovanější, což je u logické hry spíše na škodu. Také fakt, že paprsky se od zrcadel odráží podle toho, na jaké zrcadlo zrovna míříte (tedy jaký tvar má) a ne podle toho, pod jakým úhlem zrcadlo je, nepůsobí úplně přesvědčivě. 
Hlavní problém Archaica – The Path of Light je ten, že vás možná neudrží. Ano, vypadá naprosto úžasně, mechaniky jsou (ve většině případů) funkční a ovládání pomocí levého a pravého tlačítka myši je skvěle zpracované. Jenomže, co dál. Jste nosič světla, takže je tak nějak jasné, že na konci hry světlo někam donesete a svět zachráníte. Kvůli něčemu takovému se nemusíte několik hodit trápit s laserovými hádankami. 
Archaica – The Path of Light je hra pro ty, kteří si chtějí namáhat mozkové závity a opravdu je to baví. TI, kteří hledají jednoduchou zábavu, budou spíše velmi záhy frustrování úrovní puzzlí a nedočkavě čekat na zpřístupnění nápověd.

[h1]What is Archaica?[/h1]

Archaica is an indie puzzle game developed by Two Mammoths. All throughout the game you try to match lasers with crystals of the same colour, which even though this game is a  casual relaxing game, makes you think hard about the placement of you mirrors and also makes you plan how you can match colour with colour.

[h1]Detailed Review[/h1]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The puzzle element of Archaica is very well done using an intuitive style. It was challenging having to manoeuvre the lasers around the map using mirrors splitters and other objects. The sole aim is to match the lasers with a crystal that is the same colour, sometimes having to mix colours given like mixing blue and red lasers to get purple, and then sometimes having to also split one of the colours away to get that main colour for example having to connect to a red, blue and purple crystal. All this mixing and matching is controlled with mirrors, what I call ‘splitters’ and amplifiers. You use the mirrors to move the direction of laser around corners at either a 90 degree angle or with an angled mirror at a 45 degree angle. As well as mirrors you can use splitters to split the beam into 2 allowing you to take it to 2 or more crystals or allowing you to mix the colours. The final one is the amplifier this boosts the laser so it can reach further. All these elements must be placed on different squares on the level making you think about the placement so you can move the lasers correctly to the crystal. This is an element Archaica has nailed bringing me thoughtful and enjoyable times.

Throughout the levels there are also collectables like crystals, stone keys and stone slates that contain hieroglyphs. These collectables can be distracting from the game even though they do serve a purpose, these are still a bit tedious and I would rather just have the actual puzzle part of the game.

[h1]Story[/h1]

Achaica’s story is interesting, giving a back story to the barren deserts and thehistory of this world, but sadly I feel it has been poorly implemented. The story was more a side thing only being shown through a few cutscenes and through the different collectables . Personally I didn’t take much note of the story and mainly just focused on the core puzzles. The backstory of this game designed but and it would have been way more interesting if they implemented the story better, like adding more cutscenes and not having lots of it found in collectables that aren’t really a main part of the game. Otherwise I found the Archaica backstory to be interesting and would have loved it. Though this is just an issue in my opinion and it didn’t take away from the game or the story itself, it just made it harder to learn more about the world.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

Archaica looks beautiful, it looks realistic but also cartoony making it look great. It uses lighting and colours to give it its graphical style. The looks of this game are defiantly a plus and when I launched it, it was something I quite enjoyed.

[h1]Sound[/h1]

The sound in this game is also well done, the sound effects and the music are placed nicely throughout the game. The music gives you the mood of the game and is enjoyable to listen to. The sound effects are also well made.

 [h1]Pros[/h1]
  -  Puzzles well made
  -  Great Graphics
  -  Well designed sound

[h1]Cons[/h1]
  -  Poorly implemented story
  -  Annoying collectables

35113710.review:
[h1]A lasers puzzle game cranked up to the max! Awesome graphics, extremely wide range of difficulty and tons of variety.[/h1]

The first thing that strikes you when you start up the game is the gob-smacking beauty of it. It's like a UE4 game which is totally unexpected in the puzzle genre, for me at least. It's all in 3D and you're introduced to the main menu by a camera panning cutscene that glides you to the exquisitely-lit stone monument where you can select your levels. Here there is also a Totem that records your achievements by activating each stone block that lights up with a blue glow.

You click Play and the next uncompleted level is loaded. Every level starts with an appetizer of an easy hidden object game. There are 2 or 3 white crystals to find and usually (not always) Cryptoglyphs (half-buried glowing tablets). The crystals activate the hints; the Cryptoglyphs show you a short cutscene and a poetic verse of some ancient lore involving battles, pseudo-historic events and so forth. Once in a while it will refer to the mechanics of the level you're about to attempt. This part of the level is always very easy, you drag the scene around to find the objects, and the area is not very large so it rarely takes more than a minute or so. Then it's on to the main course with the lasers.

If you've ever played Lara Croft GO, you'll find the level layout very familiar. The puzzle is totally different, of course, but you drag the scene around in the same way; hidden object aspect is the same, the board grid is the same and even the environments could be swapped between the two. I had to double-check to see if it was the same developer, but no. Anyway, I'm not complaining, it's all very pleasant.

So you're presented with a grid containing a number of mirrors (there are 90 and 45 degree types) and various types of tools such as power boosters, colour-change crystals, beam splitters... there are at least a dozen different types, and more are introduced as you progress. The goal is to position and rotate these items on the board in order to guide the laser beams to light up the exit crystals with the correct colours. Blending and splitting the coloured beams to get the right colour is often necessary, so the obvious route is rarely the solution. For example, in the early stages I would position my mirrors in the spots where I expected them to be, switch them around and try various arrangements, then finally succumb to the hints... which would reveal the positions to be in weird places on the board that I never would have expected. It's fiendish!

As you light up each target, a portion of the 'solution circle' lights up. When you've successfully lit up all targets and the solution circle is fully lit, you click it to trigger a cutscene and sometimes an animation of the stonework of the level moving around and taking you to the next level. All very slick indeed.

[h1]Sound & Vision[/h1]

There are five main themed Areas: Desert City, Eternal Islands, Crystal Mines, Jungle, Temples and each is more beautiful than the last. It's not exactly flashy and the levels have a limited area, but the use of lovely glowing colours, swaying plants, glittering water and so forth makes it feel so stylish and upmarket. The background music, if you can call it that, it also nicely understated so as not to interfere with your concentration. A gentle drumbeat, occasional chime or bird call to break the silence, no more than that. Every level has an imaginative and wistful name, there is no numbering here at all.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]

This is the type of puzzler I love where you can decide for yourself how hardcore you want to play it. If you're a purist you'll complete the levels without using the hints. I think I managed to beat most, if not all of the first area without hints. By the second area I started to struggle and was tempted more and more by the hints. By the third area my pride was well and truly in the bin, and I was routinely taking all hints immediately. After the initial 2 or 3 hints it forces you to wait for a while before allowing any further hints, giving you a chance to maintain at least some dignity. The thing is, even after you've mashed the hints circle to reveal the whole board you only have a set of positions. You still don't know which item goes where, and in what rotation, so it's still hard even with hints!

Some levels have bonus difficulty where you have to light up Stone Keys to reveal hidden levels. These are extra tough, and thankfully they're optional so you can leave them for later. There's an achievement for these, of course.

There are NO TIMERS WHATSOEVER within the game. A big plus for me! A puzzle should be a relaxing, thoughtful affair in my opinion - not an artificial race against time.

[h1]Steam[/h1]

It has the lot - Trading Cards, Cloud Saves and Achievements - which are represented very nicely in-game as well as via Steam. There are no plans for Linux, unfortunately, which is a bit of a disappointment for me in an otherwise perfect game.

[h1]Value[/h1]

I know what you're thinking. This is just a lasers puzzler, it's going to get repetitive. I can honestly say that the game is packed with variety and no two puzzles are remotely similar. Amazing to think how much has been done with a seemingly limited mechanic. There are 62 puzzles (in 42 levels) + secret levels and additional puzzles needed to unlock them. By the time you get past the first couple of areas, you're talking about a good hour or so to beat a level, especially without hints, so I'd say this is well worth full price.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

There's one word for this: classy. Every aspect of it has been expertly crafted and the result is a lavish feast of puzzling, fit for a king... or pharaoh or whatever they're called in this lore.

A top contender for my puzzle game of the year.

Archaica: The Path of Light – красивейшая головоломка от польского дуэта разработчиков из студии «Two Mammoths», представленная в виде популярных пазлов с зеркалами и светом, которые нужно привести к какой-либо точке.

Сюжет игры не рассказывается на прямую, а косвенно указывается в мегалитах на секретных уровнях и криптографах, соответственно, на обычных. Мы играем за некого избранного человека, который должен пройти долгий и тернистый путь, чтобы провести лучи через дорогу света и победить тьму. Все это разбавляет постепенное усложнение уровней, а также описание объектов из альманаха, вроде различных зеркал или усилителя луча. К слову о секретных уровнях: ключи к ним, как и криптографы или ячейки (подсказки) разбросаны по уровням, чтобы в итоге собрать несколько штук и перейти на уровень не просто повышенной сложности, а уровень с уникальным местом.

Графическое оформление выполнено просто великолепно, каждые локации между кругами (и не только) выполненыв разных местах, будь то пустыни или вулканы, на которых присутствуют свои эффекты: ветер в горах или песчаные бури в уже упомянутых пустынях. Звуковое сопровождение не представляет собой ничего необычного или разнообразного, просто однообразные успокаивающие треки с элементами звуков природы.

Кроме вышеперечисленных преимуществ в игре недавно был добавлен русский язык, что есть весьма редко явление в современном инди игропроме, включая даже славянских разработчиков. Может следующие преймущества и будут весьма натянутыми, но упомянуть их я просто не могу: достижения (в игре представленные в виде анимированного тотема) и дорогие карточки. В итоге мы имеем уникальную головоломку весьма популярного типа с качественным содержанием. Great puzzle game. As a kid, I was enchanted by one of these old light reflect games, in the early days of PC games when people ran MS-DOS. Archaica is like an evolved, modern version of that. The visuals are beautiful, the sound creates a nice ambiance and a magical feel to your actions. There are plenty of different puzzle pieces to influence light in many ways, from reflection and splitting to teleporting and refracting. 

There are two things that I find less good. The first is the story. It doesn't matter much, but if you're going to put a story in your game, make it fitting. This particular type of story is not one I would put in a puzzle game. It seems at odds with the atmosphere of the gameplay. 

Second: the difficulty. Maybe it's because I don't play puzzle games often, but this game is hard. I often find 4 or 5 near-solutions, where I could solve the puzzle if I could turn one mirror into another, or have one more tile of space. Sometimes after a long time of staring at variations of what I already made, I find the "real" solution, but sometimes I don't. 

There is a hint system, but it doesn't help with this. Knowing the location of a piece but not knowing which piece is supposed to go there barely reduces the difficulty at all. The only thing that worked for me is using the hint system to get all locations, but then it's suddenly very easy and just a matter of swapping stuff until it works. So instead, I've been using the solutions post on the Steam discussion forums when I really couldn't figure one out. Usually it's one small thing that I missed. For example, "a color changing lens can be used to change the color of 2 orthogonal beams". I had one puzzle all figured out except for that one fact. The hint system does nothing in that case, except funnel you into the right direction until by pure coincidence you stumble upon the solution. 

I think this game could benefit from a difficulty setting, where the current, single-solution game could be the highest difficulty, and one lower (medium) could give you a few extra tiles of space or an extra mirror here and there, to allow for secondary solutions for the non-hardcore puzzlers. 

[b]Conclusion:[/b] Great game, as good as puzzle games get, as long as you don't care too much for story and don't mind a high difficulty.

[h1]Perfect Puzzler[/h1]

Archaica: The Path of Light uses a fairly well known puzzle method - reflecting light off mirrors to reach a target. This has been used as a mini-game mechanic in adventure games (as well as an education tool) many times, but Archaica takes the concept to the next level and bundles it up in an extremely attractive package.

There are a set amount of mirrors on a level and you can move and rotate them. By deciding where to place them and in which direction they point, different shaped mirrors refract the light in different directions. Some amplify the strength of the beam whilst some split it into two directions. The aim is to activate pillars to complete the level - some of which require two different colours to blend into a new one. There are also other puzzle elements, like activating keystones to unlock secret levels, filling orbs to trigger map changes and other mechanics that I'll let you explore.

[h1]Visual Utopia[/h1]

The gameplay concept alone wouldn't have hooked me although it certainly is good; what really drew me in was the visuals. The maps are stunningly detailed. Through beams of light we explore ruins and unlock ancient magics. If you really stop and study a map you can see the time and effort that went into the artwork. It's not just the maps, it's the menus, the achievement screen, the cutscenes/animations (of which there are plenty, simple but very effective). I've never looked at an achievement screen before and said "wow", but as you unlock achievements you light up and activate an ancient totem, making progression feel very satisfying.

[h1]A Deep World[/h1]

[i]“Many of the Light Bearers have faced The Initiation Ring, although not all were worthy it must be said.”[/i]

This is an entire world to unlock, not just a simple light puzzler. On each level there are lore items to unlock - optional environmental collectibles that provide an interesting narrative and add a hunt and seek element of gameplay. By finding cells you can also power up hints, so if you need a little nudge you can get it. The lore of this ancient abandoned world and the Light Bearers who used to control it is surprisingly deep and interesting. It's rare to find a puzzle game that puts this much work into the back story and universe.

[h1]Polish(ed) Package[/h1]

Archaica has been polished until it's sparkling. It's a full package that I rarely see from a small indie development studio. It has a genuine atmosphere that you often don't find in puzzle games. On the surface, this is a very simple puzzle concept - but everything about it just feels satisfying. It's on a custom engine and founded by two Polish brothers who spent three years of their life perfecting it. All I can say is what a talented family! I've not been this excited about discovering a new indie studio in a long time - I can't wait for their next project.

I rarely review games. Only if a game really excels in what it sets out to do I feel I have to give my 2 cents. Archaica is without a doubt such a game because it does everything it wants to achieve in a mesmerising way.

Archaica is a light redirection puzzle game. It contains 87 separate puzzles that split into 6 chapters with a total of
[list]
[*]68 campaign puzzles, and
[*]19 side quest puzzles.
[/list]
The player is gradually made familiar with the basic puzzle mechanics in the first chapter and more intricate mechanics are introduced in the following chapters. Generally speaking you have to direct light beams of different colors through crystals of the same color by using mirrors, splitters, filters, etc. As to the difficulty curve, I'd say that starting from chapter 3 puzzles are getting pretty hard to solve even though some may be less difficult.

Each puzzle of Archaica is very well designed. Your goal is clearly defined and most of the time I had a pretty good understanding of how the light has to be directed in general. Puzzleing therefore mostly consisted of trying to make this general solution work with the limited resources available. It follows that in many cases, finding the actual solution resulted in a very rewarding experience.

I never had to resort to fundamental trial and error which is also due to a hint system that perfectly fits my needs. Almost all puzzles have so-called cells hidden in them. Each cell you find allows for a hint to the puzzle. And for a hint you have to select a couple of neighboring squares in the puzzle area and the game will show you in which of these fields you have to place one of your puzzle items ... not which item though. So hints only very gently nudge you into the right direction.

Further things to look for in the puzzles are so-called cryptoglyphs. Most puzzles have between two and four of these items hidden around the puzzle area. If you find all of them, you will get some explanations as to the background and the items of Archaica. Which brings me to the 'story' of the game: generally, when you solve a puzzle you will get background information about the history of Archaica or about the Path of Light that you, the player, are wandering on. In my opinion, those text bits add to the feel of the game but I can appreciate that some might find them superfluous, after all they are quite generic.

Finally, and [u]quite importantly[/u], the game has beautiful visuals that perfectly support the feeling of intrigue when solving the puzzles. There are deserts, caves, fiery pits, jungles, and more.

Having said all that, Archaica stands out amongst all light redirection puzzles I've played and I have played quite a lot. So my advice to any lover of puzzle games is to get it right away, it is well worth it's price! If you think 15€ is too much get it in the next sale.

    《Archaica: The Path Of Light》是一款解谜游戏。玩家将操纵场景中的镜子、有色玻璃等各种元件，通过反射来引导光线，照亮全部水晶以完成关卡。本作的提示系统有针对性且实用，关卡有一定收集要素，伴随着游戏进程的发展与收集品的完善，游戏也将逐步揭示它的剧情与背景故事。

    本评测写作于2017年8月30日，此时简体中文尚未推出，因此在名词翻译和对游戏的评价上可能存在偏差，请谅解。

评价：

画面：7.5/10

    场景比较细致，各色激光及其划出的轨迹拥有不错的观感，静下心来看看截图，似乎比游玩过程中感受到的画面还要好。但在实际游戏过程中，并没有什么让人惊艳的地方。

音乐：6/10

    作为一款解谜游戏的音乐，曲调平和不闹腾，勉强是合格的，但我认为更适合它的词汇是“单调乏味”。

关卡：8.5/10

    提示系统既避免了玩家放弃思考，又能尽量杜绝卡关现象的出现。关卡内所需操作的元件数量适中，不会让玩家一眼看上去便无所适从。奖励关卡虽去除了提示系统，但不隶属正常关卡，并不影响通关。

游戏性：7/10

    拥有收集品与隐藏关卡，还能伴随游戏过程感受到作者安插的剧情。虽然将其称为剧情略显勉强，因为文字描述模糊且与游戏关系不大，而且相信也不会有人怀揣着拯救世界的梦想去通关这个游戏，但总归还是为解谜过程中提供了静下心来看看文字的休憩时光。

总评：7.3/10

只要肯花时间就能通关的一款解谜游戏。
